abstract.p: The purpose of this study is to perform numerical simulation for the design and optimization of three-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) controlled hypersonic inlets. An airframe/propulsion integrated module was first established for a waverider-based hypersonic vehicle at design Mach number of 6. Using this generic configuration, an MHD-based technique for large-scale inlet flow control is studied at the off-designed Mach value of 8.5. The results indicate that the inlet mass flowrate can act as an optimization criterion. Using a proper value of mass flowrate, an MHD generator possessing reasonable design parameters can effectively restore the flow field shock structure, i.e. shock-on-lip condition and improves the flow field characteristics at the combustor entrance at higher Mach number than the design value. The results further reveal that the MHD effect on the flow with higher load factor helps to extract more electric power from the external MHD generator and also helps in improving the performance of the combustor entrance.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Research on magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) and its potential applications in the area of hypersonic technology has become increasingly popular in many countries. The computational and experimental studies indicate that the heat barrier resulting from shock waves in hypersonic flight, separation in the crossing-shock boundary-layer interaction, and instability-growth-rate modification, etc., can be controlled by MHD interactions [1–4]. In the early 1990s, Russia had proposed a new concept on combined propulsion system that consisted of a turbine and an MHD enhanced scramjet for hypersonic cruised aircraft, and established the AJAX program [5, 6]. The most innovative and principal issue about the AJAX program is how to utilize the MHD system to develop an MHD bypass scramjet technology and control the inlet of the propulsion system. Kuranov and Korabelnikov [7] discussed the challenges of atmospheric cruise flight of a hydrocarbon-fuelled hypersonic flight vehicle under the AJAX concept. The results indicated that the MHD effects on the flow make it possible to enhance the specific impulse of the engine and create a controlled inlet under an off-design flight condition. Litchford et al. [8] concluded that MHD-bypass systems hold significant promise for extending the effective operating range of conventional hypersonic airbreathing engines.

By virtue of unfavourable interferences between the airframe and propulsion module, the overall integrated performance of the design is paramount to the success of any hypersonic vehicle [9–11]. Multiple inlet ramps may generate lift and minimize drag as the flow is being precompressed upstream of the engine inlet, while the cowl lip further compresses the flow for the combustor. Consequently, the thermo-flow characteristics of the inlet, such as the total pressure recovery, pressure rise, air-capturing factor, etc., can be improved. Nevertheless, at flight Mach number higher than the design value, the shocks emanated from the nose of the vehicle and corners of the ramps interact with the surfaces of inlet downstream of the cowl lip, creating multiple shock reflections inside the inlet. Consequently, the flow field inside the inlet becomes non-uniform and causes loss of total pressure, possibly the onset of boundary layer separation, and the engine remains unstarted, etc. [12]

According to the AJAX program, the inlet control can be furnished by an MHD device through the modification of the external flow upstream of the scramjet inlet to provide improvement on the engine performance at off-design conditions. Lindsey et al. [13] studied the MHD flow control within the internal inlet of a full scale. They found that the placement of the electromagnetic interaction region near the wall was the most important factor in determining the wall heat transfer and limiting drag increases. Soukhomlinov et al. [14] carried out a numerical study to simulate the scramjet inlet flow control using combined MHD and glow-discharge-plasma (GDP) effect and concluded that the simultaneous application of GDP together with MHD can enhance scramjet performance. Macheret et al. [15–17] conducted a series of studies to analyse the performances of the MHD controlled scramjet inlets under different off-designed conditions using two-dimensional (2D) numerical model. The results indicated that the virtual cowl upstream of the cowl lip could increase mass capture and kinetic energy efficiency of the inlet when the flight Mach number was less than the designed value, while a short MHD generator placed at the first compression ramp could restore the design shock configuration with a proper choice of parameters when the flight Mach number was more than the designed value.

In this study, an airframe/propulsion integrated module is constructed for a generic waverider-based hypersonic vehicle at the design Mach number of 6. Three inlet ramps are taken to compress the air flow, while shocks emanated from these ramps converge to the cowl lip and the reflecting shocks disappeared at the end of the third ramp. The inlet further compresses the flow along the spanwise direction downstream of the inlet ramps and thus increases the static pressure as an isolator. Taking the above generic configuration as a baseline design, a feasibility of utilizing MHD principle for a large-scale inlet flow control is studied at the off-designed Mach value of 8.5 by means of numerical simulation. The electrical conductivity in the air is assumed to be generated by electron beams injected along the magnetic lines, and a mathematical model is proposed accordingly. Euler equations with ponderomotive force and energy interaction terms are used for the numerical simulation. A second-order entropy-conditioned scheme proposed by Dong et al. [18, 19] is employed to solve the model equations. The scheme requires no adjustable parameters to satisfy the entropy condition.

sec.title: 2 AIRFRAME/PROPULSION INTEGRATED INLET
sec.p: Due to severe interferences between the airframe and propulsion module, the airframe/propulsion integrated inlet design becomes one of the crucial parts for the overall, fully integrated performance of the vehicle design. Hypersonic vehicle inlets can be categorized into two types, namely, the external and the sidewall compression inlets. Comparative study on those two types of inlets was performed by Chen et al. [20], where the computational and experimental results indicated that the external compression inlet would provide higher mass flow capturing ratio and pressure rise, while the sidewall compression inlet might produce higher total pressure recovery.

A practical inlet should be a compromise of both methods. In this article, an external/sidewall mixed compression inlet is presented as a part of the forebody whose lower surface may induce a multi-stage compression. Under this condition, shocks emanated from the nose of the vehicle and corners of the ramps will interact with the inlet surface downstream of the cowl lip and the reflecting shocks will disappear at the end of the third ramp. The inlet further compresses the flow field along the spanwise direction downstream of the inlet ramps, while the intercrossed shocks will disappear at the corners of sidewalls along the spanwise direction, as shown in Fig. 1. Parameters relevant to the optimal design of the inlet consist of the five compression angles θ1–θ5 (on the upper surface and the sidewalls of the inlet, respectively, as shown in Fig. 1), and the length of the forebody Lf (i.e. the axial distance from the nose to lip). As long as θ1–θ5 and α are given, the inlet geometry can be determined provided that the surface of the first ramp and the downstream surface of the inlet are kept parallel.

In order to achieve a high air-capturing factor, high total pressure recovery, and the high pressure rise at the inlet exit, relevant parameters from oblique shock theory are selected: Lf = 25 m, α=5∘,θ1=2.24∘,θ2=2.34∘,θ3=2.45∘,θ4=4.07∘,θ5=4.33∘ respectively.

sec.title: 3 MHD CONTROLLED INLET AT OFF-DESIGN CONDITION
sec.p: In order to make up the performance penalties under the off-design condition, inlets can be designed as variable-geometry capable of providing adequate performances for the Mach number under consideration and the operating range of the angle of attack. However, the variable-geometry substantially increases the overall weight of the mechanical system and complicates the design of the hypersonic vehicle. However, it is shown in references [9] to [15] that an alternative method based on MHD control can improve the inlet performances.

By creating near-surface magnetic field through magnetic coil and non-equilibrium electrical conductivity utilizing electron beams along the magnetic lines, MHD generator mounted on the first ramp near the nose of the forebody can extract energy from the high-temperature gas. By virtue of the work done by Lorentz force, j × B, the flow downstream the MHD interaction region decelerates, altering the structures of the flow field, particularly the configuration of the shock system. Through optimization of the relevant parameters of the MHD generator and the electron beams, MHD generator can bring shocks back to the cowl lip and the reflecting shocks disappear on the inlet surface.
In what follows further, the roles played by those parameters in the MHD controlled inlet at off-design conditions through numerical simulation are investigated.

sec.title: 6.3 Parametric analysis
sec.p:
Key parameters for maintaining the performances of the propulsion system include total pressure recovery ratio η, mass flow rate m·, flow mean parameter ɛ¯, pressure rise Pr, and the flow and state variables at the exit of inlet, such as the Mach number, the static and total temperatures, as well as the total pressure, etc. All the variables at the exit of the inlet are averaged with respect to m· over the cross-section of the exit, except the total pressure. On the other hand, the enthalpy extraction ratio, ηN, and electric efficiency, ηe, are the most important parameters representing the performances of the MHD generator. The enthalpy extraction ratio is defined as the ratio of the difference of total enthalpy at the entrance and exit of the external MHD generator and the total enthalpy of the incoming flow, while the electric efficiency represents the percentage of extracted electric power from the work done by the Lorentz force. The definitions of the relevant parameters are summarized in Table 4. Table 4
Key parameters

In addition, the maximum allowable static temperature for the combustor inlet ranges from 1400 to 1700 K [17]. Due to the design constraints being put forth by the tolerable temperature of the engine material and the type of the cooling methodology and to avoid the so-called ‘chocking’ effects that may add extra energy into the combustor, the inlet stagnation temperature should not exceed 3000 K [17]. Consequently, the static temperature and stagnation temperature at the exit of the inlet are very critical parameters to optimize the inlet.

sec.title: 6.3.1 Influences of effective length of ionization
sec.p:
The variations of m· with respect to Q of the external MHD generator under different values of LR are demonstrated in Fig. 10. As observed from the sketches, there is a point of inflexion that cuts every curve into two parts, upstream of which m· is almost constant, and decreases dramatically after that point. The phenomenon can be explained based on the reflecting position of the shocks emanated from the nose and corners of the ramps as follows: upstream of point of inflexion, the shocks interact with the surface of the inlet downstream of the cowl lip, while after the point of inflexion, the flow spillages. Consequently, the points of inflexion depicted in Fig. 9 are the positions under various values of LR, where the shocks interact with the cowl lip. sec.title: 6.3.3 Parametric comparisons for different load factors
sec.p: Numerical results indicate that for neutral flows at off-design case, the total pressure decreases due to the entropy-generated dissipation induced by the multiple shock reflections inside the inlet. Although the shock system is recovered to the state close to the design condition under the influences of the ionized flows, the total pressure decreases even more. Actually, it is the work done by the Lorentz force, u·(j×B), being responsible to the total pressure loss, which consists of electric power (j·E) and Joule heating (j2/σ). The electric energy is converted from the total enthalpy by the external MHD generator, while the process would inevitably induce Joule heating in the flow field.

Some parametric comparisons among typical test cases for various load factors are listed in Table 5, which include η, m·, Pr, ηN, ηe, T3, T0,3, and the optimal magnetic interaction parameter Qopt. It is seen that, there is a 30 per cent increase in Pr when the MHD flow control is applied. It is also found that under the same LR, ɛ¯ for k = 0.8 is less than the case for k = 0.5. This implies that at SOL condition, more uniform flow may be obtained at the inlet exit for larger k. Table 5

Comparative study for typical test cases at off-design Mach 8.5 reveals that Qopt at k = 0.5, and thus σmaxBmax 2 is less than the case at k = 0.8, which means that at small k, lower energy electron beams and magnetic flux density can bring the flow field back to design condition. However, the external MHD generator at k = 0.8 converts 8.33 per cent of the kinetic energy of the flow field into electric power. For converting this amount of kinetic energy into the electric power, there is only 20 per cent of the work done by the Lorentz force being dissipated through the Joule heating. For the case of k = 0.5, the external MHD generator converts only 3.23 per cent of the flow kinetic energy into the electric power, but with 50 per cent of the work done by the Lorentz force turning into the Joule heating.

It is equally important to observe that due to the lowering of Joule heating, more reductions on both static temperature and stagnation temperature at the entrance of combustor can be attained at larger values of k.

In summary, in order to bring the shocks back to the cowl lip, extracting more electric power from the external MHD generator, and improving the performances of the combustor entrance, the load factor associated with strong electron beam power and magnetic flux density should be increased.

sec.title: 7 CONCLUSION AND DISCUSSIONS
sec.p: In this study, an airframe/propulsion integrated module is established for waverider-based hypersonic vehicle at a design Mach value of 6. Three inlet ramps are taken to precompress the flow field, while shocks emanated from these ramps converged on the cowl lip and the reflecting shocks disappear at the end point of the third ramp. The inlet further compresses the flow in spanwise direction downstream of the inlet ramps to increase the static pressure as an isolator. As for the same geometry designed for Mach 6, a large-scale inlet flow control applying MHD concept was studied at off-designed Mach value of 8.5. The electrical conductivity in air was supposed to be generated by electron beams injected along the magnetic lines. The second-order entropy conditioned scheme was chosen to solve the 3D Euler equations.

Numerical simulation gave the 3D flow field over the airframe/propulsion integrated inlet at design condition and confirmed the shock system stated above. Under the off-design condition at Mach 8.5, the flow field inside the inlet became highly disturbed when the MHD control was not applied. The non-uniformities would deteriorate the performances of the inlet noticeably. Through the energy conversion and large-scale flow control process provided by an MHD generator, however, one could produce favourable parameters to restore the flow field and shock system as if the scramjet was operated under the design condition and make the flow characteristics at the combustor entrance more favourable when flying at Mach numbers higher than the designed Mach number.

There are advantages to have a large effective length of ionization, since it keeps the key parameters, namely, the optimal magnetic interaction parameter, total temperature, average Mach number, and flow mean parameter at the inlet exit small. However, it will deteriorate the inlet performances such as the mass flow rate, total pressure recovery ratio, and pressure rise.

Parametric study for different load factors also indicates that a small load factor can make the optimal magnetic interaction parameter small. This implies that only low electron beam energy and small magnetic flux density are needed to restore the flow field and shock system back to the design condition. However, a large load factor will extract more electric power from the external MHD generator and improve the performances of the inlet.
